Depression Quest is an interactive tale, rather than a game I hasten to add, that sets itself the task of emulating the experience of suffering from depression. For the most part this is achieved successfully, although due to the complex nature of the subject matter, the experience, or 'game' in itself is far from perfect.  The choice of text to respond with can at times be limited, lacking in complexity, often with one answer alluring to a positive ending, while the other choices would all be negative. Despite this, the narrative path that I was guided along had the ability to not only convey great emotion, but was emotive in itself, even reducing me to a tear or two at one point. One issue I did have was being unaware of whether there was any save game feature, fortunately the game is only around an hour long so this wasn't too much of a problem, but I was initially unaware of the length and whether I'd be able to finish it within one sitting.  To some extent my opinion may be biased, as due to my history of depression I can most certainly empathise with the main character of the story. Nevertheless, for those willing to take part in what you could call a 'Depression Simulator', there is a lot be learned from the mental condition here, or if you are like me, along with empathy there is some comfort in finding an iteration of depression other than your own. Above all this, there is a wealth of emotion to be felt from the narrative, although for the most part this is admittedly downbeat rather than happy; just a point to consider.  Either way, if you don't mind taking on a purely text based interactive story, rather than an actual game, I would most definitely recommend this title...I mean apart from anything else it's free isn't it, why not really?   All the best to all of you by the way, especially to those of you that are suffering in any form, it can get better. :)
realistic and boring

It's a text adventure game, so there's a lot of reading, which is fine. I'm not entirely sure from where I got in the story before I checked out that the characteristics of your reclusiveness are even depression -- it's more of introversion. I find myself identifying with most of what the character describes feeling, despite being a relatively happy person, so it's hard for me to say that the game does a very good job of actually conveying depression.  Now, every once in a while there are options for paths that are crossed out. I'm not quite sure what's going on there, there are clearly some things happening behind the scenes to determine what you can and can't select, but it doesn't give much agency to the player if they can't really tell, at the very least, if and why their decisions have led to fewer choices. If this formula were visible perhaps there'd be a greater connection that would convey the point more.  Moreover, the effect would perhaps be more dramatic if the very first choice you made didn't involve a crossed-off option, increasing the contrast when you fall deeper into depression. To be fair, the first few choices crossed off were definitely things I myself wouldn't do, and again, I'm a relatively happy person, so there's still the question of if this aided in the conveyence. If a player were able to make these decisions, establishing a character that would normally want to, then removing that option might be more powerful, but removing that option in the first place forces the establishment of a character that doesn't really help one way or the other.

Depression Quest is extremely realistic. I played through answering questions as if I was actually dealing with those situations. And, as someone who has dealt with depression all her life, I found that my answers reflected how I've actually felt before. As a result, I became profoundly depressed, and that limited what I could choose for answers. That aspect is especially realistic. When you are truly depressed, your mind can go blank and you lose the will to do things. Beautiful, realistic game. If you don't have depression, but want to know what those who do have it are going through, play this game. It's a fantastic example and can really give you an insight you didn't know you needed.

At it's best, 'Depression Quest' has the quality of a mediocre flash game. At it's worst, it has the quality of a poorly written novel. The game is short. You get exactly what you paid for. You will play it once, get through all the endings, and never touch it again. Unlike other games with multiple endings, such as 'The Stanley Parable', you can get through each ending at an extremely fast pace. And also, unlike 'The Stanley Parable', the game has no replay value, as it is not even remotely entertaining enough to play through it again. (Keep in mind, I am comparing the elements 'Depression Quest' and 'The Stanley Parable' both share, not both games as a whole.)  If you're  really  curious about this game, and also, the recent controversy surrounding it, go ahead and download it. Otherwise,  steer clear .

I honestly don't know how to feel about this interactive fiction. I mean, I don't hate it, but I can't honstly recommend it to anyone. There are some positives, though. It uses the wiki engine exceptionally well, and it even comes with controller support. Sadly, the writing and general feeling of Depression Quest just brings the entire experience down.  I get it, the protagonist is supposed to be depressed. As someone who's legitimately dealt with depression, it isn't a hard concept for me to grasp. The thing is, I don't get  why  he's depressed. He seems to be surrounded by people who legitimately care and love him, has a supposedly well paying job, and (at least in what i've seen) doesn't have the very real threat of getting thrown out of his housing situation. Even just a small amount of context would have made him a more compelling character. Without it, it just feels like 'Wah, my upper/middle-class lifestyle is so hard' has made him depressed.   Beyond that, This IF visually limits your choices, without giving you any real reason as to why. Even the illusion of a choice would have made this a much more enjoyable experience. Instead, it just comes off as 'If you're depressed, you won't be looking for a way out', something which I personally found offensive.  I probably would have liked Depression quest if it game me any real kind of context, and if the author would've given me the illusion of choice. It's really hard to care about a piece of Interactive fiction if you're never given a real reason to care.

The ending of this game states 'We realise it may not be the most enjoyable game you've ever played, or even the easiest.' The were right with the first one, but probably not the second.   Depression 'Quest' uses perhaps the loosest definition of the word 'quest'. The game is a text based RPG where you play as NAMELESS PROTAGONIST, a person who was actually surprisingly fitting for this game. His unnessecarily fortunate situation (sans depression) actually made me hate him. Which, by extension, made me - at least within the context that while playing the game, I am him - made me hate 'myself'.  I should, before I go any further, preface this by saying that I have no experience with depression, as a recipient OR as a friend of one. As such, I picked this game up mainly out of curiousity. I wanted to knowmore about the state of being, and what this person thought hepled to get out of it. Here we come to the point where I actually beleived the thing about this game being 'hard'. I found it extremely hard to actually play this 'game' properly, The writing it slow=paced and - well, frankly, it's just boring.   I understand that a game such as this isn't the kind of thing where engaging writing it easy - or even a good idea - to write. But when the game is so hard to actually get through that all I can physically bear to do is read the last chapter of the wall of text and make a decision based on that, Which, with the fact that I got what I'm pretty sure is the best ending to the game just from this, brings me to the next problem: The 'game's' difficulty.  This is the reason I've been doing airquotes around the word 'game' throughout a lot of this review. There is no failure state in depression quest. Nor is there a victory state. This game does not require any skill beyond the skill of posessing both basic logic and the LOOSEST grasp of anything even vaguely related to depression itself. It's alnost more likely that you'll be incapable of winning because you don't know how to press buttons than that you don't know what to press. Which makes me wonder how you can even define this as a game. The entire experience is just clicking a series of hyperlinks in whatever order you want so that you can make some moderate changes to the mental state of one person over the course of a few months. So not only does this game not function as a story, it isn't even really a game either.   So here comes the question of whether you should bother with this game. Well, the game takes 30 seconds-3 minutes from deciding to get it to playing. And will probably take you about 90 seconds-9 minutes to finish. Unless you are a fan of awful simulators, This will probably be less fun than any of the other games in your library, and less interesting than most of it too. So, unless you REALLY want to stick through this game and read all the horribly boring dialogue, you're better off just playing something else.  TL;DR, A boring not-really-a-game that isn't worth your time unless you're particularly interested in this one person's idea of what it means to be depressed.

I realize that work was put intot his but it just does not seem like a game at all. It is more like a online questionar (except how you answer does not matter) with some graphics. I also use to have depression and many of the things in here seem sterotypical and the parts that are not seem very obviouse.   I could see this being a storify that gets chainspammed to people or as a tumblr post. But I just can't justify calling this a game because it is not, It is a story. All you get to do is read click choices (These choice actually do nothing) and then in the end you are focued to make one final choice.

So, I read somewhere that this was a good make-your-choices game that you can play for free and it can teach you something.  I think it does a decent job to highlight the struggles someone has with depression, feelings of inadequacy, and the very steep uphill climb that one has to endure to get anywhere. I went through a period of disthymia for a few years, and arguably I'm still slogging out of it.  It does a good job at highlighting the sometimes circular problems that can come up, even when you try to make a good effort. I won't spoil what you learn, because in a way it spoils the lessons the game is trying to teach. ... But if you do decide to play it, it may take a few tries to get anything even bittersweet for results. And that's okay.  Do for yourself, even when it's hard. ... And don't go it alone.

So, I decided to play this game and give it a fair shot despite all the gamergate controversy.   The first thing I want to say, as an aspiring game developer who hopes to one day get a game through greenlight, that if this is the new standard of what constitutes the title 'game developer' then 10 year olds everywhere creating their first projects in flash can rejoice with a sense of pride in their new title of professional game developer. What do I mean by this? Well, lets take a look.   The game itself is essentially a wall of text with a couple of highlighted text that links to more walls of text. This 'game' is more or less an interactive story that follows the same format as the 'choose your own path' Goosebumps books (if anyone remembers those?) After each page of text you are given a few options of how you want to react to certain situations. Each choice will take you to a new wall of text explaining your actions and following the resulting story. Some choices close off other choices later on (I assume, otherwise the crossed out choices presented to the user are arbitrary) giving the user a sense of control over the outcomes. It follows this format until the writers couldn't think of anything else to write and thus they leave it open-ended. They explain this in the game's epilogue where they conclude that the life of a person with depression does not come to a nice and tidy ending, and thus, the game would not have such a conclusion either. This would have been believable if it were not for the games writing.   The writing is horrible. Not only is there missing commas and other punctuation that would help the reader actually understand tone and pacing of sentences, but the writing style is written at a 7th grade level. This is not an insult as many great books and stories are written with this level of vocabulary and sophistication to achieve greater audience appeal. The problem with this is that the writing randomly throws in 'big' words and pseudo intellectual vernacular to give the reader the illusion that the writers are actually smart educated people. The writing, however, speaks for itself.   This brings us to the music. I actually quite enjoyed the musical score. As a musician (I think most gamers are to some extent), I can enjoy the mood and atmosphere that the music presented. The music did achieve its goal of gradually gnawing at the player (myself) with a certain sense of beauty and anxiety. Well done!  The layout of the game was very simple. If I want to play a simple game, like cookie clicker for example, I want the user interface to be outstanding. Now, I can appreciate the fact that a game trying to give a non-depressed user a lens to perceive the world through the eyes of those who are depressed, will inevitably be a little bit more bleak and bland. This however, is not the case for Depression Quest. The interface looks like absolutely no thought went into it at all. It looks as though it was designed 100% for utility and no thought went into aesthetics.   Now, for the 'vibe' I got from the game. This game dripped with the privileged and shielded eye of a white middle class female who thinks she understands the plight of people suffering depression. It was highly offensive, as someone who has seen, first hand, the affects of depression on family members, this sort of arrogant sense of superior empathy disgusts me. This game is equivelant to a middle class white person making a game about the social-economic struggles of a black person in poverty. It is a level of arrogance that truly warrants a gamergate.

I guess you could call this an 'Interactive BawwwBlog Simulator' or perhaps label it a 'Interactive HugBox Simulator'. I think either would be fine. It's definitely one of those things but certainly not a game.   0.5/10 will not read or click again.

As someone who has his own battles with depression, I figured I would give Depression Quest a chance. I decided to put aside my views about the author (a person who can best be described as a 'terrible human being' and is NOT a 'game dev' by any stretch of the imagination) and try to be as fair and unbiased as possible.   Simply put, Depression Quest is somewhere between an interactive short story and an online questionnaire/quiz -- not a video game. If this is a video game, then those online quizzes which determine which genre of Metal you are based on your answers, are also video games. They Greenlit this? Seriously? Hmmm?  I really don't want to totally trash this interactive fiction which pretends to be a game, but this should have never been Greenlit. The only reason anyone has bothered to 'play' it is due to the fact it's free & the controversy surrounding it.

A very well put together story that captures what everyday situations are like when faced with depression and the struggles faced by many. Through this game, I believe that a lot of people could learn what it is going through the mind of someone they may know and can understand what they are dealing with. The vivid descriptions of what the character is feeling and the way others act around him are spot on.

Honestly, I have been dealing with chronic depression for a good amount of my life. The game in and of itself attempted to relate to some and much of the generic issues brought up within a 'depressed' person's life and they were quite relatable, but at some points it seems quite unrealistic and blunt. It wasn't a bad experience per say, but it feels as if the game shoe horns you into choosing the generic and or bad choice. It did well locking away the freedoms of choice one would have when experiencing depression and I appreciate that, but at times I was just bored and unimmersed with how it portrays it. Also the generic melancholy music and static felt like it was trying too hard to set the mood in my opinion. I ended up succeeding in game possibly getting a good ending, but i still didn't feel all too satisfied. Not a bad game, nor am I going into the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ background of it and its developer, but eh it wasn't as heavy as some people would expect it to be. It's worth like 1 playthru at best, do with it what you will.

It isn't so much a game as it is a choose your own path story. It does give a pretty good insight to someone with anxiety and depression, but it could be triggering. I believe it warns you about that.  If you're interested in psyche or an alternate mindset to maybe get to understand yourself or a loved one better this is the experience for you.
